data.title: Richard Nixon Gets a Comedy Show in the U.K.
data.meta_description: Richard Nixon, author of forced love letters and our nation’s 37th president, is the unlikely inspiration for a new 30-minute comedy show, to be aired on British TV next week. Conceived by and starring Harry Shearer, the American actor responsible for 21 voices on The Simpsons including Ned Flanders, Nixon’s the One features dialogue and intonations lifted directly from the tapes that were released in 2008 by the Nixon Presidential Library.
data.text:
Richard Nixon, author of forced love letters and our nation’s 37th president, is the unlikely inspiration for a new 30-minute comedy show, to be aired on British TV next week. Conceived by and starring Harry Shearer, the American actor responsible for 21 voices on The Simpsons including Ned Flanders, Nixon’s the One features dialogue and intonations lifted directly from the tapes that were released in 2008 by the Nixon Presidential Library.

Shearer, who says that he is obsessed with the scandal-plagued former leader, hopes that the one-off program will eventually make it overseas, although he adds that the non-political show lacks the “surface controversy” and pace that U.S. audiences crave. At a broadcasting lunch in London today, Shearer deadpanned that Nixon’s the One looks like “high quality surveillance video,” which is, coincidentally, more than E! can say about any of its series. President Nixon has been portrayed many times in both film and television, most notably by Anthony Hopkins, Rich Little, and Frank Langella.

The president is right that his opponent represents a grave threat to American democracy. So why are his surrogates mocking the people who are taking that danger seriously?
